sub_topic: Calculation of enthalpy change for a chemical reaction
message_1: What is the enthalpy change for the combustion of 2 moles of methane (CH4) at standard conditions (298 K and 1 atm pressure)?
message_2:
The combustion of methane (CH4) can be represented by the following balanced chemical equation:

CH4(g) + 2O2(g) → CO2(g) + 2H2O(l)

The standard enthalpy change of combustion for one mole of methane (ΔH°c) is -890.3 kJ/mol.

To find the enthalpy change for the combustion of 2 moles of methane, simply multiply the standard enthalpy change of combustion for one mole by the number of moles:

ΔH = (ΔH°c) × (number of moles)

ΔH = (-890.3 kJ/mol) × (2 mol)

ΔH = -1780.6 kJ

So, the enthalpy change for the combustion of 2 moles of methane at standard conditions is -1780.6 kJ.
